author: By Michael Gold
title: N.Y.C. will hold a virtual virus memorial event on the anniversary of the first confirmed death.
description: Thousands will be remembered during a ceremony that will be streamed on multiple platforms.
content: On Sunday, the one-year anniversary of New York City’s first reported coronavirus-related death, the city will hold a virtual memorial event honoring New Yorkers who have died of the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Roth
title: Meet the Sea Slugs That Chop Off Their Heads and Grow New Bodies
description: Their severed heads get around just fine until they regenerate perfectly functioning, parasite-free new bodies, scientists say.
content: A few years ago, Sayaka Mitoh, a Ph.D. candidate at Nara Women’s University in Japan, was perusing her lab’s vast collection of sea slugs when she stumbled upon a gruesome sight. One of the lab’s captive-raised sea slugs, an Elysia marginata, had somehow been decapitated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Has a School Assignment or Activity Ever Made You Uncomfortable?
description: Have you encountered lesson plans, class activities or school traditions that should be recognized as outdated, sexist or racist?
content: For years a high school in northwest Texas had a tradition of seniors role-playing life in the Middle Ages as part of an English class assignment that followed the reading of “Beowulf” and the works of Chaucer. The activity awarded points to students for complying with 11 “rules for chivalry.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Meghan And Harry Dressed for Oprah — And Independence
description: Meghan Markle wore Armani and Prince Harry wore J. Crew. But there was more going on.
content: So you think the clothes are beside the point in the Oprah-Harry-Meghan tell-all? You think it’s the vocal bombshells and revelations that matter, and no one is going to give two figs what the former royal couple who is uttering them is wearing? You, my friend, should think again. Costumes are always part of the program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kari Molvar
title: The New Generation of Rose Perfumes
description: A fresh crop of unisex fragrances explore the more volatile side of the beloved bloom and are refreshingly free of gender stereotypes.
content: Many of the most enduring women’s perfumes — Chanel No. 5, Joy by Jean Patou and Guerlain’s Shalimar among them — feature lush notes of rose. Indeed, the bloom’s scent has come to define a certain idea of femininity, at once tender and mysterious. In fact, though, the flower has a long history of being used in fragrances for both sexes: the ancient Greeks macerated its petals to make fragrant unisex body oils, and the “Traité des Odeurs,” an 18th-century French guide to creating aromas, includes recipes for men’s scented waters infused with “an abundance of roses,” says Saskia Wilson-Brown, the founder of the Institute for Art and Olfaction in Los Angeles. The concept of gendered perfumes only really gained traction in the 20th century — in particular after World War II, when advertising firmly reinforced the era’s gender norms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane Arraf
title: Pope Francis Ends Historic Trip at a Critical Moment for Iraq
description: Iraqi officials say the successful four-day visit is a testament to Iraqi capabilities and the battered country’s integral role in the region.
content: ERBIL, Iraq — Pope Francis concluded on Monday a trip to Iraq that made history with every step and demonstrated that Iraq, still beset by violence and recovering from decades of war and mismanagement, was able to pull off a visit that would have posed a challenge for any country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jane E. Brody
title: Medical Marijuana Is Not Regulated as Most Medicines Are
description: The industry lacks randomized controlled clinical trials that can clearly establish benefits and risks.
content: Dan Shapiro was the first person I knew to use medical marijuana. As a junior at Vassar College in 1987, he was being treated for Hodgkin’s lymphoma with potent chemotherapy that caused severe nausea and vomiting. When Dan’s mother learned that smoking marijuana could relieve the distressing side effect, to help her son, this otherwise law-abiding woman planted a garden full of the illegal weed in her Connecticut back yard.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma and Jeffrey Gettleman
title: In Nepal and Across the World, Child Marriage Is Rising
description: The pandemic has worsened economic distress and other factors that lead to such unions. Studies show a clear link between marrying early and dying young.
content: RAPTI SONARI, Nepal — Sapana dreamed of becoming a government official. Each night, in her hut along a bumpy dirt road, the 17-year-old lit a single solar-powered bulb dangling from the ceiling and hit the books, plotting out a future much different than her mother’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley and Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Cuomo Inquiry to Be Led by 2 Lawyers, Including Ex-U.S. Attorney
description: Attorney General Letitia James named a former federal prosecutor, Joon H. Kim, and an employment lawyer, Anne L. Clark, to lead the investigation that may determine the governor’s future.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — The New York State attorney general has named Joon H. Kim, a former acting U.S. attorney for the Southern District of New York, and Anne L. Clark, an employment discrimination lawyer, to lead the investigation into sexual harassment accusations made against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays, Dana Rubinstein and Emma G. Fitzsimmons
title: The A Train and the Macarena: 5 Highlights From the Mayor’s Race
description: Candidates sparred over their subway smarts and did some virtual dancing, while the former sanitation commissioner got support from influential women.
content: While Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s troubles dominated the headlines, the bevy of candidates running for New York City mayor trudged onward, dutifully showing up for yet more online forums and occasionally taking swings at their opponents’ foibles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: N.Y.P.D. Releases Secret Misconduct Records After Repeal of Shield Law
description: Inspired by racial justice protests, the Legislature repealed a law blocking police misconduct records from scrutiny. Now the outcomes of thousands of cases are available online.
content: Nearly nine months after New York lawmakers, inspired by mass protests over police brutality, repealed a law that kept the discipline records of officers secret for decades, the New York Police Department on Monday began publishing some of the sealed information.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Fareed Zakaria
title: How the Dead Hand of Imperialism Continues to Influence World Politics
description: Samir Puri’s “The Shadows of Empire” examines how the legacies of empires remain important in the “first empire-free millennium.”
content: THE SHADOWS OF EMPIREHow Imperial History Shapes Our WorldBy Samir Puri
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Many ‘Long Covid’ Patients Had No Symptoms From Their Initial Infection
description: An analysis of electronic medical records in California found that 32 percent started with asymptomatic infections but reported troubling aftereffects weeks and months later.
content: Many people who experience long-term symptoms from the coronavirus did not feel sick at all when they were initially infected, according to a new study that adds compelling information to the increasingly important issue of the lasting health impact of Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: College Sports Can Be Exploitive. They Can Also Be a Lifeline.
description: Our columnist welcomes significant changes to the amateurism rules that undergird the N.C.A.A.’s business model in the hope that young athletes might flourish, as he did, playing college sports.
content: I like to say I owe my life to college sports. In the 1950s, my father became one of the first African-Americans to play basketball at the University of Oregon. My parents met on that campus, and the scholarship my father received for his athletic skill paved the way for an education that moved our family to the middle class.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt and Christoph Koettl
title: Remote C.I.A. Base in the Sahara Steadily Grows
description: The agency has been conducting surveillance flights from the base, which has grown since 2018. Any drone strikes would be limited while the Biden administration carries out a review.
content: WASHINGTON — Deep in the Sahara, the C.I.A. is continuing to conduct secret drone flights from a small but steadily expanding air base, even as the Biden administration has temporarily limited drone strikes against suspected terrorists outside conventional war zones, such as Afghanistan, while it weighs whether to tighten Trump-era rules for such operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bryan Pietsch
title: Melee Near University of Colorado Boulder Injures 3 Officers
description: An informal gathering that swelled to as many as 800 people, most of whom were not wearing masks or social distancing, turned violent on Saturday, officials said.
content: BOULDER, Colo. — A large gathering that turned into a melee near the University of Colorado Boulder on Saturday evening left multiple students bleeding and tear-gassed, at least two vehicles damaged and three SWAT officers injured, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Vadukul
title: Monica Alexis, Nurse’s Aide With a Calling, Dies at 83
description: Ms. Alexis worked in hospitals in New York and Pennsylvania, helping her patients with “the most important things.” She died of complications of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: The Latest Wrinkle in Crumple Theory
description: From studies of “geometric frustration,” scientists learn how paper folds under pressure.
content: A piece of crumpled paper, in all of its creased fragmentations, suffers from “geometric frustration.” Who among us can’t sympathize?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alisha Haridasani Gupta
title: Biden Signs Executive Order to Advance Gender Equity
description: On International Women’s Day, the president established a Gender Policy Council that reports directly to him and that requires the participation of almost every cabinet secretary.
content: — Hillary Rodham Clinton
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Omar El-Akkad
title: Imbolo Mbue’s ‘How Beautiful We Were’ Exposes the Human Cost of Capital
description: The author of “Behold the Dreamers” sets her second novel in a fictional African village ravaged by an American oil conglomerate.
content: HOW BEAUTIFUL WE WERE By Imbolo Mbue
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: ‘Plunder,’ a Gripping Reflection on What the Nazis Took and What It Would Mean to Take It Back
description: Menachem Kaiser writes about his efforts to reclaim an apartment building in Poland that his family owned before the war.
content: Menachem Kaiser’s “Plunder: A Memoir of Family Property and Nazi Treasure” tells a twisting and reverberant and consistently enthralling story. It’s a weird story that gets weirder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Luke Broadwater
title: After a briefing by a task force investigating Capitol security, House members urge swift action.
description: Some House lawmakers on Monday urged the quick adoption of recommendations by a task force examining security shortcomings on Capitol Hill after the Jan. 6 attack on the complex by a mob of Trump supporters.
content: Some House lawmakers on Monday urged the quick adoption of recommendations by a task force examining security shortcomings on Capitol Hill after the Jan. 6 attack on the complex by a mob of Trump supporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Covid Mystery
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: It’s one of the biggest mysteries about Covid-19: Why has the death toll been relatively low across much of Africa and Asia?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Lessons From Oz: How Australian Theater Gives Broadway Hope
description: Check in with “Frozen,” “Come From Away,” “Moulin Rouge!” and “Harry Potter and the Cursed Child” in Offstage, our digital series about theater during the pandemic.
content: Theater is up and running … in Australia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Police Investigating Whether Fraternity Hazing Led to Death of Bowling Green Student
description: A 20-year-old Ohio student died three days after attending a Pi Kappa Alpha event that was said to involve alcohol-fueled hazing.
content: A 20-year-old sophomore at Bowling Green State University in Ohio died on Sunday evening, three days after attending what university officials called an off-campus fraternity event that was said to include “hazing activity involving alcohol consumption.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: What Went Right in the 2020 Election
description: It wasn’t all a mess. Here’s how the government and tech companies tamed foreign interference.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Global Warming’s Deadly Combination: Heat and Humidity
description: A new study suggests that large swaths of the tropics will experience dangerous living and working conditions if global warming isn’t limited to 1.5 degrees Celsius.
content: Here’s one more reason the world should aim to limit warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, a goal of the international Paris Agreement: It will help keep the tropics from becoming a deadly hothouse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Taimoor Shah, Fahim Abed and Jim Huylebroek
title: In One Afghan District, Peace From 8 A.M. to 5 P.M.
description: An unofficial cease-fire brokered by local officials, farmers and Taliban forces is an example of how communities, driven by despair, have engineered their own ways to stop the fighting.
content: PANJWAI, Afghanistan — For a brief moment in a small patch of southern Afghanistan, the war has stopped.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: Metro Pictures, Champion of the Pictures Generation, Is Closing
description: The gallery, which represented artists like Cindy Sherman and Robert Longo, cited “the anticipated arrival of a very different art world.”
content: After more than 40 years, the gallery famous for representing artists like Cindy Sherman, Robert Longo and Sherrie Levine has announced that it will close by the end of December.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Producers Guild Nominations Boost ‘Chicago 7’ and ‘Nomadland’
description: But some contenders were snubbed. The road to a best-picture Oscar nomination nearly always goes through this group, which may doom “Da 5 Bloods.”
content: Over the last two years, every film nominated for best picture at the Oscars was first nominated by the influential Producers Guild of America. Few awards-season precursors can offer so ironclad a guarantee.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Cracks in a Legal Shield for Officers’ Misconduct
description: The Supreme Court has hinted that it is ready to trim the doctrine of qualified immunity, which makes it difficult to sue government officials for violence and cruelty.
content: WASHINGTON — For years, the Supreme Court has been hostile to lawsuits from victims of police violence, prisoners subjected to appalling cruelty and others who sought to sue government officials for violations of their constitutional rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Buskirk
title: There Is a Generational Divide Among Republicans
description: It shows up most clearly in the debate over whether parents should get federal money for their children.
content: Where do Republicans go from here? Is it more populism? Trumpism without Trump? Trumpism with Trump? Warmed-over Reaganism? Will the party embrace a middle-class agenda? Or maybe it will just return to the anodyne mediocrity that gave Donald Trump an opening in the first place.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: The Best Bagels Are in California (Sorry, New York)
description: West Coast bakers are driving a great bagel boom, producing some of the most delicious versions around and finding ways to expand during the pandemic.
content: BERKELEY, Calif. — The bagels at Boichik Bagels have the look of Labrador puppies curled up for afternoon naps: soft and pudgy, golden roly-polys (practically made for that old puppy-or-bagel meme).
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: New Ads Looking Ahead to Closing Social Distance
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 8, 2021.
content: “It’s almost like the stages of acceptance. There’s not a light-switch approach. No one is saying, ‘Let’s pick a day and go all in.’ ”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: How long will the trial last and how can I watch?
description: Jury selection is the only part of the trial that will not be streamed live, though audio will be available. Once the jury is chosen, the trial can be watched on nytimes.com.
content: The trial of Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd will be unusual for many reasons: It will be livestreamed from Minneapolis, attendance will be severely limited because of the coronavirus, and the public’s interest in the case may make this one of the highest-profile trials in recent memory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Pence will make his first speech since leaving office.
description: The former vice president left Washington on the outs with former President Donald J. Trump, and his speech next month will be scrutinized for hints of his political future.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence is planning to make his first public remarks since leaving office in January, an appearance that is certain to be heavily scrutinized for any hints of his political ambitions in the future and clues about the status of his relationship with former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Serge F. Kovaleski
title: Alaska races against time and history to fight the virus in the most remote villages.
description: In Alaska, where the Indigenous population has been ravaged by global disease outbreaks for generations, the pandemic has killed Alaska Natives at quadruple the rate of white residents.
content: In Alaska, where the Indigenous population has been ravaged by global disease outbreaks for generations, the pandemic has killed Alaska Natives at quadruple the rate of white residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lara Jakes and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Biden Gives Venezuelans Reprieve to Remain in U.S. Trump Had Rejected
description: Hundreds of thousands of Venezuelans can temporarily continue to live and work in the United States as the administration considers its next steps in the effort to force out Venezuela’s president.
content: WASHINGTON — As many as 320,000 Venezuelans living in the United States were given an 18-month reprieve on Monday from the threat of being deported, as the Biden administration sought to highlight how dangerous that country has become under President Nicolás Maduro.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Kean
title: Could You Transplant a Head? This Real-Life Dr. Frankenstein Thought So.
description: In “Mr. Humble and Dr. Butcher,” Brandy Schillace introduces readers to a transplant surgeon with some strange but also forward-thinking ideas about the brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Hiltner and Lalena Fisher
title: How Bad Was 2020 for Tourism? Look at the Numbers.
description: The dramatic effects of the coronavirus pandemic on the travel industry and beyond are made clear in six charts.
content: Numbers alone cannot capture the scope of the losses that have mounted in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic. Data sets are crude tools for plumbing the depth of human suffering, or the immensity of our collective grief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Michigan Trooper Is Charged After Setting Dog on Man for Nearly 4 Minutes
description: The man, who the authorities said sustained several bite injuries, can be heard in dash camera footage pleading with Trooper Parker Surbrook to pull the dog off him.
content: A state trooper in Michigan has been charged with felonious assault for using a police dog to subdue an unarmed man for nearly four minutes in November, an encounter that the authorities say left the man with bite injuries and was recorded on a police dash camera.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaina Plott and Danny Hakim
title: Josh Hawley Is ‘Not Going Anywhere.’ How Did He Get Here?
description: The senator’s objection to the election results surprised some supporters. But interviews with dozens of people close to him show his growing comfort with doing what it takes to hold on to power.
content: Most Republicans who spoke at the recent Conservative Political Action Conference in Orlando, Fla., avoided acknowledging the events of Jan. 6. But less than 30 seconds into his speech, Senator Josh Hawley confronted them head on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: I Asked the Head of Space Force What the Agency Has Done for Me Lately
description: Gen. John Raymond has put up with plenty of mockery. But, he says, there’s nothing funny about protecting U.S. interests from Russian and Chinese anti-satellite technology.
content: When Space Force was announced by President Trump, late-night hosts had a field day. Jimmy Kimmel joked that the action filmmaker Michael Bay “is on board to direct the whole thing.” But for Gen. John Raymond — the agency’s actual director who has served in the military for over three decades — space is no joke. And there’s nothing funny about protecting American interests from Russian and Chinese anti-satellite technology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Building Pizzas That Can Survive the Box
description: In a time of takeout, two New York restaurants have come up with different ways of making pies that still taste good half an hour later.
content: The cardboard pizza box has a status in American culture at least equal to that of the soup can. Andy Warhol did not silk-screen them, but a Philadelphia artist named Ed Marion painted a series of portraits on them, “right where the pie would sit,” as he explained. Other artists, including Ed Hardy, contributed designs to be printed on the outside. Pizza boxes have been used as movie props, usually in the hands of eager delivery boys, and as musical instruments. When the Velvet Underground parody band the Pizza Underground performed “Take a Bite of the Wild Slice” and other reworked songs, a percussionist, Deenah Vollmer, kept time by striking a drumstick against a pizza box.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dava Sobel
title: A Biography of the Woman Who Will Re-Engineer Humans
description: In “The Code Breaker,” Walter Isaacson turns to the life and work of Jennifer Doudna, the Nobel-winning scientist who has revolutionized gene editing.
content: THE CODE BREAKERJennifer Doudna, Gene Editing, and the Future of the Human RaceBy Walter Isaacson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Cuomo Thought There Was No Limit to His Power
description: Besieged on multiple fronts, the governor is no longer holding forth; he’s just trying to hold on.
content: Gail Collins: Well, Bret, much to talk about as always. But I guess we should start with Andrew Cuomo.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Joys of Post-Pandemic Life Await. But We’re Not There Yet.
description: You’ll be back on the dance floor soon enough, just hold on a little longer.
content: It’s going to feel incredible resuming a Covid-free life again. We’re getting there. But don’t let impatient politicians, vaccine selfies, or overeager friends tempt you. As the video above explains, returning to pre-pandemic life is like taking a hot bath — jumping in too quickly will only get us burned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Manchin Expresses Openness to Making Filibuster Harder to Use
description: The moderate Democrat said he would not support killing off the procedural tool that requires bipartisan support for most bills, but signaled a willingness to advance some party-line votes.
content: WASHINGTON — Senator Joe Manchin III of West Virginia, a moderate Democrat who has often balked at efforts to alter Senate rules to allow his party to muscle through its agenda over Republican opposition, signaled a willingness on Sunday to make changes to the filibuster and support future party-line votes if bipartisan negotiations proved unsuccessful.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim and Elaina Plott
title: Josh Hawley, vilified for exhorting Jan. 6 protesters, is not backing down.
description: Speaking to the Conservative Political Action Conference in Orlando, Fla. this month, Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri — who offered an encouraging fist-pump to protesters before a some of them stormed the Capitol — confronted an image that has come to define him head-on.
content: Speaking to the Conservative Political Action Conference in Orlando, Fla. this month, Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri — who offered an encouraging fist-pump to protesters before a some of them stormed the Capitol — confronted an image that has come to define him head-on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Can Libya Put Itself Back Together Again?
description: There’s a glimmer of hope.
content: Few countries exemplify the tragedy of the Arab Spring like Libya. The fall of the 42-year dictatorship of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi brought a decade of anarchy as competing governments, militias and foreign powers struggled to seize control of the oil-rich country. The United States and NATO allies that had backed the anti-Qaddafi uprising with a bombing campaign largely turned their backs after he fell, and past United Nations efforts to forge a government foundered in the chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim, Maggie Astor and Jo Becker
title: Inside the Lincoln Project’s Secrets, Side Deals and Scandals
description: A civil war broke out in the group as it antagonized Donald Trump, with leaders splintering over financial arrangements and revelations of online harassment by a top official.
content: A few days before the presidential election, the leadership of the anti-Trump Lincoln Project gathered at the Utah home of Steve Schmidt, one of the group’s co-founders, and listened as he plotted out the organization’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Covid-19 Conundrum in Rome: More Homeless on Streets as Shelters Shrink
description: Distancing measures have forced shelters to limit capacity, leaving many homeless people vulnerable to harsh weather and other hardships.
content: ROME — On an icy evening last month, Akas Kazi, a 35-year-old originally from Bangladesh, huddled under a blanket in the portico of one of Rome’s main post offices, as Red Cross volunteers distributed hot meals of pasta and tea.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Teens on a Year That Changed Everything
description: Teens across the United States show us how they have met life's challenges in the midst of a pandemic.
content: What has it been like to be a teenager during the first year of a historic pandemic?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rory Smith
title: Weston McKennie Is Right Where He Belongs
description: What is most surprising about the American’s path to Juventus is not how far he has come, but how effortless he has made the journey look.
content: As he sat down for lunch, Weston McKennie slipped his cellphone out of his pocket and onto the chair in front of him, hiding it beneath his legs. He was breaking the rules — he and his Schalke teammates were strictly forbidden from taking their phones into the cafeteria — but he was prepared to take the risk. There are some calls you do not want to miss.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 8, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 8, 2021.
content: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 8, 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: She Was Imprisoned for Killing Her 4 Children. But Was It Their Genes All Along?
description: The case of Kathleen Folbigg has become a contest between cutting-edge science and an Australian court system that sometimes ignores it.
content: SYDNEY, Australia — The tabloids in Australia called Kathleen Folbigg a murderer of innocent babies — the nation’s “worst female serial killer.” In 2003, a court sentenced her to 40 years in prison for smothering her four children before each had turned 2.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Battered but Unbowed: How Beckett Speaks to a New Era
description: Adaptations of “Happy Days” and “First Love,” works by the master of existential wheel-spinning, show us how to live in place.
content: Stuck. Winnie is stuck. So have we all been this past year, far more than usual.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Chris Hamby
title: Biden Cancels Visit to Vaccine Maker After Times Report on Its Tactics
description: The White House scrapped a trip to a vaccine plant in Baltimore run by Emergent BioSolutions after a New York Times investigation into the company.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday canceled a visit to a coronavirus vaccine plant run by Emergent BioSolutions, and his spokeswoman announced that the administration would conduct an audit of the Strategic National Stockpile, the nation’s emergency medical reserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erin Griffith
title: How Do Silicon Valley Techies Celebrate Getting Rich in a Pandemic?
description: Not by buying airplanes. Instead, the newest start-up millionaires are proceeding cautiously.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — Things are so hot in Silicon Valley that it’s freaking people out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Beans, Beans, Beans!
description: Creamy and braised, or with greens and Parmesan, these white bean recipes won’t disappoint.
content: Good morning. I was on a call the other day with a bunch of people who’d made white beans the night before and were planning on having the leftovers for lunch. I realized I’d been shying away from white beans, I think mostly on account of a rocket someone sent to foodeditor@nytimes.com, admonishing me for writing too much about white beans in this space. (Those rockets work, folks!)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: Oil Giants Prepare to Put Carbon Back in the Ground
description: Climate concerns push BP and other firms to seek new roles as pollution fighters.
content: During more than three decades in the oil and gas business, Andy Lane has managed the construction of enormous facilities for extracting and transporting natural gas, in places like Trinidad and Indonesia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hannah Beech
title: Myanmar Military Storms Universities and Hospitals and Revokes Press Licenses
description: The military said the public had requested that the generals take more control “for the benefit of the people.”  At least three protesters were killed in further crackdowns.
content: Workplaces across Myanmar were shuttered on Monday, part of a general strike aimed at strangling the power of military rulers who toppled an elected government last month. But if manufacturing and commerce were idled, anger at the brutality of the military flared further, despite the increased presence of security forces in urban centers and a tougher clampdown on the press.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow
title: The Crossword Stumper
description: A look at one of the entries that fooled solvers in last week’s puzzles.
content: EMO is a genre of rock music. It is heavily influenced by punk rock and features introspective, emotionally fraught lyrics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ernesto Londoño and Letícia Casado
title: Brazil’s Ex-President ‘Lula’ May Run for Office Again as Court Cases Are Tossed
description: A decision by a Supreme Court justice sets the stage for former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva to run against President Jair Bolsonaro in next year’s presidential contest.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — A Supreme Court justice in Brazil on Monday tossed out several criminal cases against former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, restoring his right to seek the presidency again, in a decision with the potential to reshape Brazil’s political future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: Making Chess Sing: ‘Queen’s Gambit’ to Be Adapted for the Stage
description: A creative team has not yet been set for the proposed show, which would be based on the 1983 novel that spawned the hit streaming series.
content: Beth Harmon is making her next move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Oprah, Meghan and Harry Draw 17.1 Million Viewers to CBS
description: A two-hour special revived a faded TV genre, the “big-get” prime-time interview that once drew tens of millions for exclusive sit-downs with people like Michael Jackson and Monica Lewinsky.
content: Oprah, Meghan and Harry drew a sizable audience on Sunday night, making for an old-style prime-time television moment in the age of on-demand viewing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Prince Harry Finally Takes On White Privilege: His Own
description: Meghan Markle and Harry’s interview revealed a catalyst for their reinvention, our critic writes: Harry’s racial awakening after attacks on Markle.
content: It was well worth the wait. The first joint interview with Prince Harry and Meghan Markle since they stepped down from royal life last year (a process that became officially permanent last month) did not disappoint.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Chamath Palihapitiya’s ‘Super Tough Week’
description: The SPAC mogul defended a big stock sale.
content: One of the most prominent names in SPACs, Chamath Palihapitiya, faced backlash last week after regulatory filings showed that he had sold his entire personal stake in Virgin Galactic, which he took public through a blank-check fund. (He will stay on as chairman, and will indirectly remain a shareholder through an investment firm that owns a stake in the company.) The news — coming as shares of many SPACs, as well as Virgin Galactic’s, tumbled amid a broader market decline — added to concerns about a blank-check bubble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The Allies’ Betrayal of George Floyd
description: Did the summer’s protests reflect a racial reckoning or seasonal solidarity?
content: Something happened this summer in the wake of the killing of George Floyd, and maybe only history will be able to fully explain what it was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Live Event: Covid-19 One Year Later
description: How do we come to terms with what we’ve lost? How do we make sense of what comes next?
content: In March 2020, the World Health Organization declared Covid-19 a global pandemic. Since then, the coronavirus has claimed more than 2.5 million lives globally, including more than 500,000 people in the United States. Behind these unfathomable numbers are countless more lives upended forever — by the loss of loved ones, of jobs and of the joys of everyday life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Judith Levitt
title: Vaccinations, Schools, Meghan Fallout: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: For Perfectly Light Schnitzel, Do This
description: J. Kenji López-Alt was looking for the secret to an evenly golden, puffed schnitzel. He found it, and his recipe puts a new spin on an Austrian technique.
content: SEATTLE — It’s 1 a.m., and I’m standing at the stove, swirling my wok and watching waves of melted lard pass over a pork cutlet that is verging on the perfect shade of gold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gia Kourlas
title: A Ballerina Takes a Leap of Faith, This Time in Herself
description: Lauren Lovette, the New York City Ballet principal, is retiring from the company but not from dance.
content: In November, on her 29th birthday, Lauren Lovette cut off her hair, and posted about it on Instagram. Last week, this New York City Ballet principal, who brings a singular breath of fresh air to her dancing, announced she would be retiring from the company. That haircut was more than a haircut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Azi Paybarah
title: Police Officer Is Shot While Responding to Armed Confrontation in Brooklyn
description: The officer was in stable condition after being struck in the chest by a shot that hit his bulletproof vest, the authorities said.
content: A New York City police officer was hospitalized in stable condition after being shot in the chest on Sunday night while responding to an armed confrontation at an apartment building in Brooklyn, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: The C.D.C. says vaccinated people can gather inside without precautions.
content: The United States inched toward post-Covid life today, as the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention issued long-awaited guidance to Americans who have been fully vaccinated. Notably, the guidelines allow vaccinated people to engage in new activities, including gathering indoors in small groups without precautions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Toilet Brushes
description: Because everyone needs one — and it doesn’t have to be ugly.
content: The toilet brush may be one of the least glamorous things in your home, but it’s still worth having one that isn’t completely off-putting. That’s because it’s a tool that — like it or not — is always on display, sitting beside the toilet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: Democratic Leaders of N.Y. Legislature Take Aim at Cuomo
description: As the governor maintained a defiant stance,  the leader of the State Senate became the most prominent official to call on him to step down.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Roy Blunt of Missouri, No. 4 Senate Republican, Plans to Retire
description: Mr. Blunt, a fixture of Republican leadership in Congress who had been known for his ability to work with both parties, said he would not seek re-election in 2022.
content: WASHINGTON — Roy Blunt of Missouri, the No. 4 Senate Republican, announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election in 2022, the latest in a string of party veterans who have opted to exit Congress as the G.O.P. remakes itself in the mold of former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: Pope Francis Defends Iraq Trip During Coronavirus Pandemic
description: The pontiff said that he had wrestled with the decision to travel, but put the fate of the Iraqis who flocked to see him in God’s hands.
content: ABOARD THE PAPAL PLANE — Pope Francis, lamenting that he felt like he was in “prison” under lockdown in the Vatican, said on Monday that he had wrestled with his decision to visit Iraq in the midst of a pandemic but ultimately chose put in God’s hands the fate of the Iraqis who gathered in crowded churches, often without masks, to see him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melina Delkic
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Shock waves from the Harry and Meghan interview.
content: Hours after the interview was broadcast in the U.S. on Sunday, Britain was already grappling with the shock wave rippling out across the Atlantic, exposing a deep royal rift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Carla Wallenda, Surefooted Mainstay of a High-Wire Act, Dies at 85
description: The last surviving child of the Flying Wallendas’ founder, she was with the troupe for seven decades, performing heart-stopping aerial stunts into her 80s.
content: Carla Wallenda, who spent seven decades with both her head and her feet in the clouds (or close to them) as a member of the Flying Wallendas aerial act, died on Saturday in Sarasota, Fla. The last surviving child of the family troupe’s founder, she was 85.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: U.S. Lawmakers Suggest 25 Movies About Latinos to the Film Registry
description: By diversifying the films added to the national registry, members of Congress hope that more opportunities will open up for Latinos in Hollywood.
content: The Congressional Hispanic Caucus is continuing work it started in January, when it nominated the movie “Selena” for the National Film Registry, with a list of 25 more films it would like to see the registry add.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s Dilemmas, Part 2: Children at the Border
description: In the second part of our look at the issues the current administration is facing, we examine the president’s response to the growing number of minors at the border.
content: The number of unaccompanied children arriving at the U.S.-Mexico border is growing — and, with it, the anxiety within the Biden administration. This is President Biden’s first real immigration challenge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: Severe Obesity Raises Risk of Covid-19 Hospitalization and Death, Study Finds
description: A large new study has confirmed an association between obesity and patient outcomes among people who contract the coronavirus.
content: Over the past year, many scientific teams around the world have reported that obese people who contract the coronavirus are especially likely to become dangerously ill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.7 Million Homes in California
description: A 1928 Tudor Revival in Sacramento, an updated ranch house in Topanga and a circa-1900 cottage in San Francisco.
content: The Fab Forties area of the East Sacramento neighborhood has wide streets lined with houses in some of the early 20th century’s most popular styles, including Tudor Revival. The seller of this house, an interior designer, refinished the hardwood floors, updated the kitchen and installed new light fixtures and hardware in the style of the home’s original pieces.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Women Report Worse Side Effects After a Covid Vaccine
description: Men and women tend to respond differently to many kinds of vaccines. That’s probably because of a mix of factors, including hormones, genes and the dosing of the shots.
content: On the morning that Shelly Kendeffy received her second dose of the Moderna Covid-19 vaccine, she felt fine. By afternoon, she noticed a sore arm and body aches, and by evening, it felt like the flu.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Morning at Night: Live Event
description: The beloved newsletter breaks out of your inbox for a special live briefing from David Leonhardt.
content: Every weekday, The Morning Newsletter helps millions of readers make sense of the day’s news and ideas. Now, for the first time, join David Leonhardt on Thursday, April 15, at 7 p.m. Eastern time for a special live edition, created just for subscribers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: Of Nazis, Crimes and Punishment
description: Some offenses are so hideous that even the distance of history offers no shield. But that doesn’t make justice easy.
content: NASHVILLE — Two weeks ago, the U.S. government deported Friedrich Karl Berger, a longtime resident of Oak Ridge, Tenn., for participating in Nazi war crimes. Mr. Berger was returned to Germany, where authorities have declined to press charges of their own. He had lived in the United States since 1959.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘A Teenager Was Bullied. His Ancestors Saved Him.’
description: In this lesson, students will reflect on their relationships to their family history as they learn about one young person’s search for, and connection to, his family’s story.
content: Featured Article: “A Teenager Was Bullied. His Ancestors Saved Him.” by John Leland
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: For Women in Music, Equality Remains Out of Reach
description: The latest study by the Annenberg Inclusion Initiative at the University of Southern California found that women’s representation in music has not improved in the last decade.
content: Three years ago, an academic tallied up the performers, producers and songwriters behind hit songs, and found that women’s representation fell on a scale between, roughly, poor and abysmal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choire Sicha
title: How to watch the Meghan and Harry Oprah interview in the U.K.
description: It will show at 9 p.m. on ITV.
content: The two-hour interview conducted by Oprah Winfrey with Prince Harry and Meghan Markle aired on Sunday in the United States — first on the East Coast, with a repeat for the West Coast. On the main network that aired it, more than 17 million people watched.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise
title: The Officers Danced at a Black Lives Matter Rally. Then They Stormed the Capitol.
description: What appeared to be racial progress in rural Virginia turned into bitter conflict over a Confederate statue, the election and the Capitol riot. Now, people there foresee “a very dangerous time.”
content: ROCKY MOUNT, Va. — One sunny day last spring, Bridgette Craighead was dancing the Electric Slide with three police officers in the grass next to the farmers’ market. It was the first Black Lives Matter protest this rural Virginia county had ever had, and Ms. Craighead, a 29-year-old hairdresser, had organized it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Why is Archie not a prince? Meghan says there’s more to it than following the rules.
description: Why is Archie, the young son of Prince Harry and Meghan, not a prince? That emerged as a murky question in the aftermath of the couple’s generally revealing interview with Oprah Winfrey.
content: Why is Archie, the young son of Prince Harry and Meghan, not a prince? That emerged as a murky question in the aftermath of the couple’s generally revealing interview with Oprah Winfrey.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Joe Drape
title: The three days last March that changed sports.
description: It took just three days last March for nearly every sport to shut down because of the coronavirus outbreak.
content: It took just three days last March for nearly every sport to shut down because of the coronavirus outbreak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: ‘I Just Didn’t Want to Be Alive Anymore’: Meghan Says Life as Royal Made Her Suicidal
description: In a bombshell interview with Oprah Winfrey, the Duchess of Sussex said she had asked officials at Buckingham Palace for medical help but was told it would damage the institution.
content: A year after Meghan Markle married Prince Harry in a fairy-tale wedding, she said in an extraordinary interview broadcast on Sunday night, her life as a member of the British royal family had become so emotionally desolate that she contemplated suicide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Newman, Téa Kvetenadze and Nate Schweber
title: 10-Year-Old Boy Is Found Dead, Covered in Cuts and Bruises
description: The boy, Ayden Wolfe, was found unconscious in his Harlem living room, and a man who lived with him was charged with murder. “I don’t understand what went wrong,” a relative said.
content: A 10-year-old boy was killed in his apartment in Harlem over the weekend, and his mother’s boyfriend was arrested and charged with his murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: Meghan and Harry recount conversations with royals about their son’s skin tone.
description: Meghan told Oprah that there were “concerns and conversations about how dark his skin might be.”
content: Oprah seemed genuinely shocked by the revelation: Meghan offering a secondhand account of conversations Harry had had with his family on the subject of their then-unborn first child’s skin tone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eliza Shapiro
title: New York City High Schools Will Reopen in Pandemic Milestone
description: The 488 public schools will reopen March 22, though the majority of students will continue learning from home. High schools in other large districts may not reopen for months.
content: New York City will welcome high school students back into classrooms starting on March 22, Mayor Bill de Blasio announced on Monday, a major milestone in the city’s sometimes halting efforts to resume in-person instruction for some of its one million students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Miriam Jordan
title: Taking the Vaccine Into the Fields to Help Vulnerable Farmworkers
description: Monday: A mobile clinic brings the vaccine to workers deemed essential. Also: Another reopening update.
content: (This article is part of the California Today newsletter. Sign up to get it delivered to your inbox.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Syria’s leader, Bashar al-Assad, and his wife have tested positive for the virus.
description: The Assads experienced mild symptoms and will continue working during quarantine, his office said. The news comes just ahead of the 10-year anniversary of the start of the country’s civil war.
content: President Bashar al-Assad of Syria and his wife, Asma, have tested positive for the coronavirus after experiencing mild symptoms, Mr. al-Assad’s office said on Monday. The pair are in good health and will continue work while quarantining at home for at least two weeks, his office added.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Nicholson
title: ‘Bombay Rose’ Review: Nostalgic Ruminations
description: A romance between a refugee and an escaped child bride is at the heart of this animated film.
content: The wistful animation “Bombay Rose” (streaming on Netflix) paints modern day Mumbai as an impressionistic cityscape where blurry street merchants hawk blobs that might be marigolds or oranges or heaps of turmeric. It’s as if the director, Gitanjali Rao, sharpens her focus only on the faces of two star-crossed lovers — Salim (voiced by Amit Deondi), a refugee from Kashmir, and Kamala (Cyli Khare), an escaped child bride — who sell flowers on opposite sides of a thoroughfare.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: In Biden, Labor Leaders See a President Who ‘Is Not Playing’
description: He has put organized labor at the heart of his plan to rebuild the economy, signaling a break with previous administrations of both parties.
content: As Richard Trumka stepped out of the Oval Office last month after meeting with President Biden and a group of his fellow labor leaders, he had an unfamiliar feeling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: It’s a girl: Meghan and Harry reveal that Archie will have a sister.
description: Prince Harry and Meghan Markle used the occasion of the Oprah interview to tell the world their second child will be a girl.
content: It was just last month that Prince Harry and Meghan Markle announced they were expecting their second child, doing so on the anniversary of Princess Diana’s disclosure that she was pregnant with her own second child — Harry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: bequeath
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: For U.K., Meghan and Harry Interview Resurfaces Issues of Race and Royal Tradition
description: Many Black Britons found that the interview raised new questions about entrenched racism, both in the royal family and in British society at large.
content: LONDON — Hours after an interview with Prince Harry and his wife Meghan was broadcast in the United States on Sunday, Britain was already grappling with the shock wave rippling out across the Atlantic, exposing a deep royal rift.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Smith
title: They Had a Fun Pandemic. You Can Read About It in Print.
description: A downtown New York crowd is pushing back against the homogenization of big social media.
content: Honor Levy, 23, with a piece of fiction published on The New Yorker’s website and a short story collection coming out next year, was regretting her decision to pull her piece from The Drunken Canal as we walked last Thursday past the publication’s unmarked white newspaper box in Lower Manhattan. But her friend and editor, Claire Banse, also 23, had told her the paper had already hit its quota on the word “retarded” and she’d objected. (What else rhymes with “departed”?) Now, her short story wouldn’t appear in the fifth and largest issue of the paper, whose mystique would only be enlarged by the fact that Ms. Banse’s co-editor, Michelle Guterman, who goes by “Gutes,” had closed the issue while experiencing Covid-19 symptoms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall and Tariro Mzezewa
title: What We Learned From Meghan and Harry’s Interview
description: The Sussexes accused the royal family of failing to protect them, both emotionally and financially.
content: Oprah Winfrey’s interview with Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, the Duchess of Sussex, had been teased for days. So it was a shock to find when it aired Sunday night that it included a number of explosive revelations about the couple and their fraught relationship with the British royal family.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Erica L. Green
title: Biden Will Revisit Trump Rules on Campus Sexual Assault
description: The Biden administration will examine regulations by Betsy DeVos that gave the force of law to rules that granted more due-process rights to students accused of sexual assault.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday directed the Education Department to conduct an expansive review of all policies on sex and gender discrimination and violence in schools, effectively beginning his promised effort to dismantle Trump-era rules on sexual misconduct that afforded greater protections to students accused of assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Backs Georgia College Student’s Free Speech Suit
description: The 8-to-1 ruling said courts may hear suits seeking only nominal damages. Chief Justice John G. Roberts Jr., dissenting, said the majority had turned judges into advice columnists.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday that a student in Georgia could pursue a lawsuit challenging speech restrictions at his college even though he sought only nominal damages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Masks Aren’t Just for Catchers: Spring Training in Photographs
description: Traditions are everything in baseball, and the sport is making many of them work despite the pandemic.
content: In a sport known for its adherence to tradition, spring training is a throwback even by baseball’s standards: fans sitting among scouts and executives; players working their way into shape while chatting with people hanging over outfield walls; and small stadiums geared more toward enjoying the game than making money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: These Y.M.C.A. Camps Served Children for 100 Years. Now They Are Shut.
description: The Y.M.C.A. of Greater New York is selling three summer camps that have been a bucolic retreat for generations of poor children from the city, part of the pandemic’s economic fallout.
content: Juan Escobar was 12 and skinny when he first went to a Y.M.C.A. summer camp. He weighed only 65 pounds, often didn’t get enough to eat and had chronic asthma.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Itzkoff
title: How the ‘WandaVision’ Creator Brought Her Vision (and Wanda’s) to Life
description: Jac Schaeffer shared some of the secrets behind the show’s origins, its Marvel-size finale and those impossibly catchy tunes.
content: This interview includes spoilers for the entire season of “WandaVision.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Blake Griffin Agrees to Sign With the Nets
description: A six-time All-Star, Griffin will be another big name on a Nets team stacked with them, but he has appeared in only 38 games since the 2018-19 season.
content: Blake Griffin, a six-time N.B.A. All-Star, signed with the Nets on Monday, one day after clearing waivers and becoming a free agent, the team announced.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roni Caryn Rabin
title: Vaccinated Americans, Let the Unmasked Gatherings Begin (but Start Small)
description: The C.D.C. on Monday released long-awaited advice for immunized people, a glimpse at the next stage of the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Federal health officials on Monday told millions of Americans now vaccinated against the coronavirus that they could again embrace a few long-denied freedoms, like gathering in small groups at home without masks or social distancing, offering a hopeful glimpse at the next phase of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: Teaching and Learning With the Coming of Age Project
description: Teens across the U.S. showed us how this pandemic year has challenged and changed them. Here are some ways to use their work in the classroom.
content: Last fall, The Learning Network invited teenagers across the United States to document their lives and tell us — in words or images, audio or video — what this tumultuous year has been like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Who Will Win Record of the Year at the Grammys? Let’s Discuss.
description: Beyoncé, Megan Thee Stallion, Billie Eilish, Dua Lipa and more will face off Sunday. In this special “Diary of a Song” episode, critics for The New York Times break down the show’s premier category.
content: At the 63rd annual Grammy Awards on Sunday, there will be no shortage of big-name matchups in the major categories (Taylor Swift! Dua Lipa! Roddy Ricch!), but only one has the real heavyweight showdown: Beyoncé vs. Beyoncé.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Drive-Throughs That Predict Your Order? Restaurants Are Thinking Fast
description: Inspired by pandemic lessons that kept customers in cars, chains are adding more lanes and curbside pickup, improving apps and testing menu boards that use artificial intelligence.
content: Starbucks has employees at hundreds of busy locations strolling through car lines, taking orders with hand-held devices so customers can get their caffeine fix a few seconds faster. Shake Shack, which has long emphasized that quality ingredients are worth waiting a few extra minutes for, will soon feature its first drive-through window. And the vast majority of new Chipotles this year will have “Chipotlanes,” where customers can drive up to a window and pull away with preordered meals in less than a minute.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: With Reminders to ‘Play Boldly,’ Bryson DeChambeau Wins Arnold Palmer Invitational
description: DeChambeau had counsel in the form of an old letter from Palmer and texts from Tiger Woods as he won his first tournament of the year.
content: ORLANDO, Fla. — After sinking a testing five-foot par putt on the 18th hole to win the Arnold Palmer Invitational here on Sunday evening, Bryson DeChambeau said he had received a text message from Tiger Woods that morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Coming to America’ and the Grammy Awards
description: The original “Coming to America” airs on Paramount Network. And this year’s Grammy Awards airs on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 8-14. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Olivia Rodrigo and Morgan Wallen Dominate the Charts After Eight Weeks
description: The 18-year-old singer and actress’s song “Drivers License” holds at the top of Billboard’s Hot 100 chart, and the country star’s LP repeats at No. 1 on the Top 200.
content: In late 1966, Elektra Records signed a new band called the Doors, and the label had a feeling its debut was special. To prevent the album from getting lost in the crowded fourth-quarter market, Elektra released it at the start of the next year, when it faced scant competition. “The Doors” became a sensation, eventually reaching No. 2 on the Billboard chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Meghan says she sought help from the palace for suicidal thoughts, but was rebuffed.
description: In an emotional disclosure, Meghan Markle described suffering persistent suicidal thoughts during her pregnancy after bullying from the news media and being barred from leaving the house.
content: In an emotional and arresting disclosure, Meghan Markle described approaching Prince Harry and the royal family and seeking help with persistent suicidal thoughts during her pregnancy, after months of bullying from the press and being barred from leaving the house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush and Katie Rogers
title: Biden will deliver a prime-time address on Thursday, marking the first anniversary of the pandemic in the U.S.
description: The speech will be forward-looking, a spokeswoman said, and Mr. Biden plans to highlight “the role that Americans will play” in getting the country “back to normal.”
content: President Biden will deliver the first prime-time address of his presidency on Thursday, marking one year since the adoption of sweeping measures to deal with the coronavirus pandemic, which subsequently killed more than 525,000 Americans and battered the economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Israel reopens to its vaccinated populace.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: ‘Allen v. Farrow’ Episode 3 Recap: Investigations and a Custody Trial
description: Filmmakers delve into dozens of boxes of records that documented the investigations into Dylan Farrow’s accusation of sexual abuse.
content: In the previous episode of “Allen v. Farrow,” the HBO documentary series that examines Dylan Farrow’s accusation of sexual abuse against her father, Woody Allen, the filmmakers introduced viewers to key video footage of a 7-year-old Dylan explaining events to her mother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: Cornel West Is Leaving Harvard After Tenure Dispute
description: The public intellectual and professor of African-American studies will head to Union Theological Seminary in New York.
content: Cornel West is abandoning his quest for tenure at Harvard and going back to Union Theological Seminary, where he first taught 44 years ago, the New York seminary announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Casey
title: The Pandemic’s Silver Lining? This Village May Have Been Saved by It.
description: Gósol, a tiny village on the Spanish side of the Pyrenees, had spent years begging outsiders to come repopulate it. Since 2020, many have come to try the quiet life — and they even saved the school from closing.
content: GÓSOL, Spain — The castle that crowns the hill above the village of Gósol used to be among the grandest along Spain’s border with France, with views of fertile farms and forests rich in timber that stretched up to the cloudy mountaintops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Giannis Antetokounmpo Was the All-Star Who Couldn’t Miss
description: A 16-for-16 night by the Milwaukee Bucks star highlighted a game that many players didn’t really want to play.
content: ATLANTA — Giannis Antetokounmpo of the Milwaukee Bucks unintentionally banked in two of his three 3-pointers. He took 11 shots in the first half, and five more in the second half, without missing one. He also made a priceless memory with his infant son before the game even started, leaning down to Liam Antetokounmpo at courtside for some quick ball-handling work as the opening tip approached.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Party Is Coming. Here’s What to Wear.
description: Designers have looked into their crystal balls and predicted the future. It’s fancy. Ideas from Loewe, Versace and Thom Browne — plus a hard-core Givenchy.
content: To a certain extent every designer is also a prognosticator; a seer, looking six months or even a year into the future and predicting what we will want to wear. Which really means: Who will we be? What costume will we need to define us?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Los Angeles Schools Remain Closed and Families Wonder: How Much Longer?
description: Even amid signs of a deal with the teachers’ union, the district is still probably a month or more from resuming in-person learning.
content: It has been almost a year since the coronavirus pandemic virtually emptied public schools in Los Angeles and sent Shamael Al-Alim home to take classes from her bedroom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronica Penney
title: How Coronavirus Has Changed New York City Transit, in One Chart
description: Public transit ridership fell sharply and still hasn’t recovered.
content: Public transit ridership fell sharply and still hasn’t recovered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Mali?
description: Can you find Mali on a map? What else do you know about this African country with about 20 million people?

title: What You Get for $1.7 Million in California
description: A 1928 Tudor Revival in Sacramento, an updated ranch house in Topanga and a circa-1900 cottage in San Francisco.

author: By Office Of The New York City Mayor
title: N.Y.C. to Commemorate One Year Since First Covid-19 Death
description: New Yorkers will honor those who have died of Covid-19 during a virtual memorial event on Sunday, the one-year anniversary of New York City’s first confirmed virus-related death.
content: New Yorkers will honor those who have died of Covid-19 during a virtual memorial event on Sunday, the one-year anniversary of New York City’s first confirmed virus-related death.

author: By The Associated Press and Reuters
title: C.D.C. Outlines Covid-19 Advice for Vaccinated Americans
description: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Monday that people who have been fully vaccinated can hold small gatherings indoors without masks or social distancing.
content: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention announced on Monday that people who have been fully vaccinated can hold small gatherings indoors without masks or social distancing.

author: By Tala Schlossberg
title: The Joys of Post-Pandemic Life Await. But We’re Not There Yet.
description: You’ll be back on the dance floor soon enough, just hold on a little longer.
content: You’ll be back on the dance floor soon enough, just hold on a little longer.

title: Diary of a Song Breaks Down the Grammys
description: Beyoncé, Megan Thee Stallion, Billie Eilish, Dua Lipa and more will face off this weekend for record of the year. In this special Diary of a Song episode, The New York Times’ pop music team dissects the award show’s premier category.

author: By Reuters
title: Biden Elevates Two Female Generals on International Women’s Day
description: President Biden on Monday announced the nominations of Gen. Jacqueline D. Van Ovost and Lt. Gen. Laura J. Richardson to be the second and third women to lead a Combatant Command in the U.S. military.
content: President Biden on Monday announced the nominations of Gen. Jacqueline D. Van Ovost and Lt. Gen. Laura J. Richardson to be the second and third women to lead a Combatant Command in the U.S. military.

title: Highlights From Harry and Meghan’s Interview With Oprah
